qas.question: What has served as a school of writing for many authors?
Who spread Buddhist texts in East Asia?
What did translators shape in the course of their work?
What have translators acted as by conveying knowledge between cultures?
Where were idioms and vocabulary imported from?
What has served as an enemy of writing for many authors?
Who spread Buddhist texts in South America?
What did translators lose in the course of their work?
What have translators acted as by conveying ignorance between cultures?
Where were idioms and vocabulary hidden from?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Translation<b5_0/><a0_0/> has served as a school of writing for many authors. Translators, including <a1_0><b6_0>monks<b6_0/><a1_0/> who spread Buddhist texts in East Asia, and the early modern European translators of the Bible, in the course of their work have shaped the very <a2_0><b7_0>languages<b7_0/><a2_0/> into which they have translated. They have acted as <a3_0><b8_0>bridges<b8_0/><a3_0/> for conveying knowledge between cultures; and along with ideas, they have imported from the <a4_0><b9_0>source languages<b9_0/><a4_0/>, into their own languages, loanwords and calques of grammatical structures, idioms and vocabulary.
